awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop and provide publicly available computer codes and documentation intended to assist in solving problems in quantum dynamics using high-level programming languages and high-performance computers (HPC).  These resources will enable researchers to more effectively utilize the nation's investment in HPC, advancing the pace of scientific discovery and innovation. Of particular interest are applications of quantum dynamics to both ultracold atoms and to nuclear astrophysics. For example, a theory of quantum hydrodynamics is needed to properly describe recent experiments with confined ultracold gases and could also lay the foundation for a resolution of the 40-year old mystery of pulsar glitches, sudden increases in the spinning of neutron stars even though they continually lose angular momentum. Both undergraduate and graduate students will be trained with the analytical and high-performance computational skills to succeed in their future pursuits in academia, at national laboratories, or in industry.  A superfluid explorer will be developed, enabling people to experience the fascinating properties of our quantum universe.

This theoretical work will be applied to three types of cold-atom experiments at Washington State University (WSU) and the University of Washington (UW).  The first are Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) with various interactions such as induced spin-orbit coupling.  Here, a variety of exotic phenomena will be studied, including negative-mass hydrodynamics, and soliton dynamics.  The theoretical approach will be refined as required to incorporate the effects of finite temperature and dissipation.  The second class of applications is to experiments with coupled superfluids which explore the physics of entrainment and other superfluid interactions.  Finally, the project will explore whether and how experiments with fermionic superfluids can model the proton and neutron superfluids in neutron stars.  Understanding these quantum phenomena will directly advance the field of cold atoms, unlocking potential applications in quantum technology, such as improved sensing and quantum computing.  The underlying theory will also advance other fields, including condensed matter, non-linear optics, nuclear theory, and nuclear astrophysics.

por.por_cntn:
Ultra-cold quantum gases (cold atoms) provide a tunable experimental platform which can be used as an analog quantum computer to study new quantum phenomena.  While we await the technological advances needed to scale up digital quantum computers to where they can solve pressing scientific problems, analog quantum computers in the form of cold-atom experiments can study new phenomena today.

This program studies quantum dynamics in both fermionic and bosonic superfluids, developing theoretical techniques in close collaboration with experimental groups to study quantum dynamics in a variety of contexts. By explaining experimental results, we validate our theoretical techniques which we will ultimately used to understand the behavior of neutron stars, in particular, pulsar glitches, which are conjecture to arise from instabilities in superfluid dynamics from quantum turbulence, vortex pinning, and superfluid entrainment.

Intellectual Merit: In this project we explained an experimental result that found shockwaves in a superfluid with spin-orbit coupling (SOC) to be more stable when propagating into a region of negative-mass hydrodynamics. By matching these results with microscopic simulations, we showed that vortex dynamics (quantum turbulence) play a key role, suggesting that SOC may be used as a tool to adjust the effective viscosity in future quantum simulations of neutron stars.

A second outcome was the development of an experimental protocol to measure superfluid entrainment (the Andreev-Bashkin effect) by embedding a bosonic superfluid (Yb) in a rotating fermionic superfluid (Li) and using atom interferometry.  Superfluid entrainment is expected to play an important role in neutron stars, but has yet to be demonstrated experimentally.  We show how to use cold atoms experiments to measure this effect for the first time.

A third outcome was the demonstration and theoretical explanation of of gravitational caustics seen experimentally in an atom laser.  Similar to cuastics in light, cusp and fold cuastics in atom lasers are fully categorized by catastrophe theory.  Unlike light, however, atoms respond strongly to gravity, allowing these experiments to study gravitational effects that typically require cosmological scales to see in light. Quantum catastrophe theory is a new field with interesting potential applications, such as advanced beam-shaping which might be used in high-resolution lithography.

A fourth outcome was the generation of the largest fermionic quantum turbulence simulations to date using the Summit supercomputer.  These simulations will help us understand the nature of quantum turbulence, develop experimental signatures for detecting quantum turbulence in cold atom experiments where imaging is typically destructive, and validate the theoretical techniques needed to understand quantum turbulence in neutron stars.


Broader Impacts: 10 graduate students and 3 undergraduate students were trained as part of this program, learning a combination of high-performance computing techniques, and quantum physics.

We have publicly released our superfluid dynamics codes - the W-SLDA toolkit - capable of effectively utilizing the largest computers in the world.  These codes demonstrate strong scaling, and fully utilize the GPU accelerators that provide current supercomputers with the majority of their computing power.

To help train students to use these simulations, we have built an interactive superfluid dynamics explorer called super_hydro and provided accompanying tutorials which take students from scratch through the process of building a high-performance simulation in python that can utilize GPU acceleration.

This super_hydro application allows people to interact in real-time with superfluid simulations, enabling them to develop an intuition for how superfluids behave.  The application can be used by those without any programming or physics skills to explore superfluid behavior (and is on display in our department), or can be extended by those with modest programming skills to demonstrate and explore new superfluid systems.

  • Gravitational caustics in an atom laser explained by an embedded sheet in 3D space (x, z, t) (inset, and with gravity removed in the main panel). Folds and cusps - the only generic types of caustics here - appear when this sheet has vertical tangents.
    Nature Commun. 12; 7226 (2021)
    Copyrighted
    Michael M Forbes
    Gravitational caustics with an Atom Laser.
  • Atom interferometer proposed to the Andreev-Bashkin effect. As the bosonic (Yb) superfluid confined to this ring with a notch expands, it produces an interference pattern whose phase is sensitive to entrainment with a circulating fermionic (Li) superfluid (not shown).
    Khalid Hossain [arXiv:2111.12335]
    Copyrighted
    Michael M Forbes
    Ring interferometer to detect superfluid entrainment.
  • Asymmetric shockwave propagation in a BEC with spin-orbit coupling (SOC). SOC breaks Galilean invariance and results in different left- vs right-moving flow. Shockwave stability on the right suggests a lower effective viscosity, implying that this may be tuned in quantum simulations with SOC.
    Phys. Rev. A 102, 053310 (2020)
    Copyrighted
    Michael M Forbes
    Asymmetric shockwave propagation in a BEC with SOC.
  • 3D quantum turbulence (72x72x72 periodic box) in the unitary Fermi gas (UFG), which can be realized in cold atom experiments, but is also is a good model for the neutron superfluid in the crusts of neutron stars where it may explain the origin of pulsar glitches.
    Michael McNeil Forbes
    Copyrighted
    Michael M Forbes
    3D Quantum Turbulence.
  • Snapshot of the Super_Hydro superfluid hydrodynamics explorer showing a demonstration of a rotating fluid with a vortex lattice in the core and tracer particles which help demonstration the flow. Users can interact in real-time with the application to develop their intuition about superfluids.
    Michael McNeil Forbes
    Copyrighted
    Michael M Forbes
    Vortices and Tracer Particles in the Super_Hydro Explorer.
